Article.Title: Georgia Power, PSC staff reach agreement on new electricity rates
Preview: Georgia Power and staff for state regulators reached an agreement for the company to back off some of the steepest electricity rate increases it had proposed charging its 2.7 million customers over the next three years, according to a filing released Wednesday.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Text messages reveal alleged effort to redraw Democrat out of ...
Preview: Text messages and emails obtained by The Atlanta Journal-Constitution reveal how Public Service Commission Chairman Tricia Pridemore and Commissioner Tim Echols discussed district boundaries and the address of Echols' potential Democratic opponent.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Georgia Power's Vogtle spending climbs, but no new delays forecast
Preview: Georgia Power spent more than $500 million dollars on the two new nuclear reactors at Plant Vogtle in the first half of this year and it may take another $1 billion to complete the project, the company said Wednesday.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Vogtle co-owner moves to freeze costs, shift more to Georgia Power
Preview: Oglethorpe Power pulled a release valve to exercise a one-time option to cap the construction costs it will have to pay for Plant Vogtle Units 3 and 4 at $8.1 billion.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Atlanta welcomes first-ever female Hungarian 'Freedom Fighter' statue
Preview: On the 66th anniversary of Hungary’s 1956 uprising against the country’s Soviet government, a group of diplomats, survivors of the revolution and their families gathered in Atlanta Sunday to dedicate a new statue honoring the “Freedom Fighters” who stood up to the oppressive Communist regime.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Negotiations over Georgia Power's rate hikes appear to stall
Preview: Georgia Power and staff for state utility regulators appear to be in a stalemate over the company’s request to raise its electricity rates, people with knowledge of the negotiations tell The Atlanta Journal-Constitution.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: More record heat grips Georgia, threatening vulnerable populations
Preview: Another spell of extremely high temperatures gripped Atlanta on Wednesday and is expected to stick around on Thursday, as the remnants of a heat wave that shattered temperature records across the Upper Midwest and Great Plains settles over the Southeast.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: As heat waves grow more frequent, researchers hunt for Atlanta's ...
Preview: Climate scientists say extreme heat events, like the one Atlanta experienced this week, bear the fingerprints of human-caused climate change. And as the city warms, a new initiative is aiming to capture a fuller picture of the heat risk faced in different neighborhoods.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: How do PFAS enter our bodies? Emory researchers want to find out
Preview: A group of Emory researchers have received $250,000 in new federal funding to investigate how PFAS chemicals get into our bodies.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Court decision will allow Georgia Power to recover coal ash costs ...
Preview: A ruling this week by Georgia’s highest court means Georgia Power’s rate payers will continue to foot the bill for some of the cost of storing the company’s coal ash around the state, under the terms of a plan approved by state utility regulators.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Rivian opponents sue to halt excavation work on Georgia EV plant site
Preview: Residents near the future $5 billion Rivian electric vehicle plant sued Friday to try to stop grading work on the property, alleging the site isn’t properly zoned and that local officials are turning a blind eye.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Ohio decision could affect Georgia Power's plans for storing coal ash
Preview: A federal agency’s decision to stop an Ohio power company from dumping more toxic coal ash in an unlined pond has brought fresh scrutiny to Georgia Power’s own waste storage plans and whether they could cost the company and, potentially, ratepayers down the line.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Georgia utility commission elections off again after U.S. Supreme ...
Preview: November elections for two Georgia Public Service Commission seats may not be held after the U.S. Supreme Court vacated an appeals court decision in a voting rights case and the state dropped its push for a stay that may have kept the races on ballots this fall, citing the fast-approaching election.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Georgia Power begins loading fuel into one of Plant Vogtle's new units
Preview: Georgia Power announced early Friday morning that engineers at Plant Vogtle have begun loading fuel into the first of two new reactors at the site, a significant step toward generating electricity from the first commercial nuclear units built in the U.S. in three decades.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Georgia solar industry faces headwinds at home and abroad
Preview: After being hamstrung for months by supply chain constraints, reaction from Georgia solar companies to moves this week by the White House to boost clean energy has been mixed.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Gulf remains between Georgia Power, PSC staff over rate hike ...
Preview: Witnesses for Georgia Power, environmental groups and members of the public delivered their closing arguments this week before state utility regulators at the Georgia Public Service Commission (PSC) decide whether to approve or pare back a nearly 12% rate hike the company wants to impose on customers over the next three years.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Plant Vogtle reaches major milestone with one of its new reactors
Preview: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission authorized fuel to be loaded into a new reactor at Plant Vogtle.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Southern Company joins bid to land regional hydrogen hub
Preview: Southern Company, the parent company of Georgia Power, is joining many of the Southeast’s largest utilities to launch joint bid to bring a hydrogen hub to the region.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: What the Supreme Court's greenhouse gas ruling could mean for ...
Preview: Experts say the Supreme Court’s decision to rein in the Environmental Protection Agency’s authority to limit greenhouse gas emissions likely won't stop the transition away from coal-fired power plants, but may lead to a wave of new litigation challenging other environmental regulations.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Hurricane seasons are starting earlier. Scientists think they know why
Preview: The window for dangerous tropical storms to form is shifting earlier in the calendar year, new research has found, with potential impacts on Georgians living on the coast and farther inland.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: After legal roller coaster, judge rules Democrat can stay in PSC race
Preview: A judge ruled Thursday that Patty Durand, a Democratic candidate for the Georgia Public Service Commission, can stay in the race for the District 2 seat because the state’s residency requirements are unconstitutional as applied to her case.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Georgia Power tries burning hydrogen as it seeks fossil fuel ...
Preview: Georgia Power conducted several successful tests this month to explore whether hydrogen — the universe’s most abundant element — could be another alternative for the company to generate power and reduce dependence on fossil fuels.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Fishermen sue claiming Golden Ray pollution is still hurting business
Preview: A group of fishermen and other members of coastal Georgia’s tourism economy have sued companies connected to the Golden Ray containership for damages, alleging pollutants released during the incident and cleanup have caused lasting harm to their businesses.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: City council passes modest updates to Atlanta's tree ordinance
Preview: Atlanta city council passed several revisions to the city’s dated tree ordinance on Monday, representing the first new measures approved in years aimed at protecting the city’s trademark tree canopy.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Monitors blame Georgia Power's lax oversight for Plant Vogtle delays
Preview: Monitors enlisted by state regulators to track construction of the two new nuclear units at Plant Vogtle recently criticized Georgia Power, Southern Nuclear and their subcontractors’ management of the project, claiming their lax oversight has contributed to delays and skyrocketing costs.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Proposed Georgia Power rate increase to be heard by PSC
Preview: Georgia Power's 2.7 million customers would start paying much more on their monthly power bills starting next year if the utility's proposed rate increase is approved.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Coalition wants to bring regional hydrogen hub to Georgia
Preview: A coalition assembled by Sen. Jon Ossoff, that includes Atlanta Mayor Andre Dickens and more than 20 other Georgia business, academic and clean energy leaders, is seeking to bring one of several proposed hydrogen hubs to the region.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Medical device company Boston Scientific plans $62.5 million facility ...
Preview: Medical device producer Boston Scientific plans to build a new $62.5 million manufacturing and supply chain facility in Johns Creek, Gov. Brian Kemp’s office announced Tuesday.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Critics warn Georgia Power's proposed rate hikes won't be the last
Preview: Witnesses for Georgia Power testified for hours in front of state regulators this week to justify the company’s plan to raise rates by nearly 12% over the next three years.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Climate bill could be a game changer for Georgia solar. Here's why
Preview: After the Senate’s passage of the Inflation Reduction Act, panel producers and clean energy advocates say few states are better positioned than Georgia to capitalize on the brighter days that lie ahead for the solar industry.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Tests find 'forever chemicals' in Chattahoochee, other Georgia rivers
Preview: So-called “forever chemicals” have been detected in several Georgia rivers, including the Chattahoochee River, which serves as the primary source of drinking water for the city of Atlanta, according to a new report.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Feel like 2022 has been hotter than normal in Atlanta? You'd be right
Preview: The first six months of 2022 has been one of the hottest starts to a year in Atlanta’s recorded history, according to a new analysis of federal data.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Cumberland Island on Georgia coast could see more visitors. Will it ...
Preview: When Congress made Cumberland Island as a national seashore, the rules were clear: The wildlife refuge on Georgia’s coast would be managed differently than most parks. The NPS is accepting comments until Friday on a proposed increase in daily visitors
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Vogtle co-owners take Georgia Power to court over cost disputes
Preview: As two long-delayed nuclear reactors at Plant Vogtle appear to be nearing completion, two of the units’ co-owners have taken their partner, Georgia Power, to court in a dispute over who should bear the brunt of the project’s rising costs.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Update: Warnock introduces EV tax credit bill to give grace period to ...
Preview: U.S. Sen. Raphael Warnock plans to introduce a bill Thursday to tweak requirements for electric vehicle tax credits in President Joe Biden’s signature climate and health law.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Extreme heat drives major jump in Southern Company's second ...
Preview: Hot weather and high fuel costs in the first half of the year drove a huge jump in Southern Company’s earnings in the second quarter, the company announced Thursday.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Georgia Power still opposed to expanding popular rooftop solar ...
Preview: Georgia Power said last week it remains opposed to expanding a popular solar program advocates say would encourage more households to install panels on their roofs.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Rome in Northwest Georgia grapples with toxic 'forever chemicals' in ...
Preview: “Forever chemicals” have been used for decades to add oil-, water-, and heat-resistance to dozens of products — from pans and food wrappers to fabric and carpets. But their stubborn resistance to breaking down in nature and the proliferation of PFAS-treated products means traces can be found even in some of the most remote environments on Earth. Residents of Rome, Georgia are experiencing that firsthand.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: State regulators approve Georgia Power rate hike
Preview: In a 4-1 vote Tuesday, state regulators at the Georgia Public Service Commission (PSC) approved a plan that will allow Georgia Power to raise rates and collect roughly $1.8 billion more from its customers through 2025.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Georgia farmers scramble to save harvests as Hurricane Ian ...
Preview: South Georgia farmers, still stung by Hurricane Michael four years ago, are keeping wary eyes on the skies as Hurricane Ian approaches.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Bird flu detected in Georgia backyard flock, agency says
Preview: For the first time this year, a highly contagious variant of bird flu has been detected in a domestic flock in Georgia, the state’s Department of Agriculture announced Thursday.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: As rising temps reshape Georgia's fruit industry, citrus takes root
Preview: A look at how climate change is affecting Georgia produce farmers. Even if they don’t believe in human-caused climate change, farmers across South Georgia are having to adjust to changes in the growing season, precipitation, heat and other factors. This story would be a window into the practical implications of climate change and Georgia’s top industry.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Big Georgia companies keep silent after Supreme Court abortion ...
Preview: Many of Georgia's largest companies have declined to comment publicly about how they will respond to the state's new abortion law.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Georgia Power seeks rate hike of nearly 12% over three years
Preview: As fears of a recession grow and inflation remains near a 40-year high, Georgia Power announced Friday that it is asking state regulators to approve an electricity rate hike of nearly 12% over the next three years for its 2.7 million customers.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Scrap metal plant fined $311k for 'serious' health, safety violations
Preview: An Atlanta scrap metal facility that drew the attention of federal environmental regulators earlier this year was cited by U.S. Department of Labor investigators for a host of workplace violations, including failing to keep surfaces clear of lead and exposing employees to a litany of other dangers, including possible amputation.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: As Rivian works to clear permit hurdles, residents want site details
Preview: At a state-organized meeting Wednesday to address local residents concerns about Rivian’s $5 billion EV factory, a company representative defended its environmental track record and reiterated its commitment to protecting local water supplies and wildlife habitats.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Fertilizer or pollutant? Soil amendments cause stir in rural Georgia
Preview: Soil amendments have been used on Georgia farms for years and are regulated by the state Department of Agriculture. But their use ― and what’s allowed under Georgia law — has turned into an issue in this year’s contest for Agriculture Commissioner, with one of the two major candidates having played a leading role in weakening local regulatory authority.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Agreement sheds light on Georgia Power's evolving energy plans
Preview: Georgia Power is likely to shelve its battery storage system aspirations for now, while tweaking its method for containing coal ash at one power plant, according to a new agreement filed this week with state utility regulators on the company’s long-range energy plans.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Democratic candidate faces court challenge to eligibility for PSC seat
Preview: The winner of the Democratic primary for a Georgia Public Service Commission seat is facing a legal challenge to her eligibility based on a residency requirement.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Georgia Power to wean off coal, add gas and solar under approved ...
Preview: State regulators voted Thursday to approve Georgia Power’s long-term plan for generating and distributing electricity, allowing the company to continue its phase out of its remaining coal-fired power plants and replace them with natural gas and solar energy.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Mining company Twin Pines sues over Army Corps' ruling on ...
Preview: The company behind a years-long quest to mine for titanium at the edge of the Okefenokee National Wildlife Refuge has filed a new lawsuit over a recent ruling that restored federal oversight of the project.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Ag commissioner candidates spar over sludge spreading controversy
Preview: The three candidates seeking to become Georgia’s next Agriculture Commissioner took the debate stage Monday, sparring over nuisances that have besieged parts of the state and their readiness to guide the state’s powerhouse agriculture industry.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Cloud software acquisition completed with Cox Enterprises investment
Preview: OpenGov, a software company known for its cloud services geared toward state and local governments, announced this week it has acquired Cartegraph, another public agency-focused cloud software developer, with new funding from Atlanta-based Cox Enterprises.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: New project aims to map Atlanta's air pollution divide
Preview: A new federally-funded research partnership between a local nonprofit, Georgia Tech researchers and local schools will explore the impacts of air pollution on children on the city’s mostly Black and historically neglected south side.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Cargill and Continental Grain acquire chicken giant Sanderson Farms
Preview: Two of the world’s biggest food conglomerates announced Friday that they have acquired Sanderson Farms and will merge it with another chicken producer, forming a new poultry giant that will be headquartered in Georgia.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: U.S. Army Corps sued over controversial Okefenokee mining project
Preview: Four conservation groups sued the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers Tuesday in federal court over a decision this summer to remove itself from reviewing the environmental impact of a mine planned near the Okefenokee Swamp, which placed permitting for the project back in the hands of state environmental regulators.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Hyundai factory groundbreaking highlights EV promise and ...
Preview: The groundbreaking at a $5 billion Hyundai electric vehicle plant near Savannah shows the EV industry is moving into a higher gear. It comes as Rivian begins construction on a similarly sized plant near Atlanta. But that doesn't mean there aren't obstacles in the road, including changes to tax credits and lawsuits against local incentives.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: City Hall calls regulators' rooftop solar decision 'disappointing'
Preview: Days after the Georgia Public Service Commission’s (PSC) vote to allow Georgia Power to collect $1.8 billion from its customers over the next three years, the city of Atlanta is praising some aspects of the plan, but called regulators’ decision not to grow a popular rooftop solar program “disappointing.”
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Bird flu outbreak reported at Noah's Ark Animal Sanctuary in Henry ...
Preview: A number of birds have been killed in an outbreak of bird flu at Noah’s Ark Animal Sanctuary, south of Atlanta, state officials confirmed Monday, the latest cases in Georgia during what has been an active season for the virus nationwide.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Harper wins agriculture commissioner race
Preview: Republican state Sen. Tyler Harper will become Georgia’s next agriculture commissioner, according to the Associated Press.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Georgia Power's 'Smart Usage' rate plan draws scrutiny
Preview: Georgia Power says its “Smart Usage” rate plan is designed to offer consumers an incentive to use energy at times of lower demand and save money. But that’s not the way it’s working out, Georgia Public Service Commission public interest staffers and other experts testified this week during hearings on the company’s proposal to raise its electricity rates.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Hyundai breaks ground on massive Georgia EV plant
Preview: Hyundai Motor Group held a ceremonial groundbreaking Tuesday near Savannah for its $5.54 billion electric vehicle “Metaplant,” the company's biggest investment outside South Korea and the largest economic development project in Georgia history.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Yeezy fallout with Adidas leads to layoffs at Georgia shoe ...
Preview: Adidas’ decision to end its lucrative partnership with the rapper Ye, formerly known as Kanye West, in the wake of his recent antisemitic comments is triggering layoffs at a local shoe manufacturer.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Vogtle co-owner votes to halt its spending on the nuclear project
Preview: Weeks after two other co-owners of the nuclear units under construction at Plant Vogtle took Georgia Power to court in a cost dispute, the board of Dalton Utilities voted this week to halt its spending on the reactors, citing concerns over the project’s rising price tag.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Harper, Hemingway vie to bring new leadership to state's Ag Dept.
Preview: For only the third time in over half a century, Georgia’s Department of Agriculture will have a new leader in 2023, with Republican state Sen. Tyler Harper and Democrat Nakita Hemingway, Libertarian David Raudabaugh and independent Mollie Beavers running to lead the agency.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Georgia to phase in new rules banning some wild animals as pets
Preview: State regulators are placing new limits on which wild animals can be bought, sold and kept as pets in Georgia, citing the threat invasive species pose to the state’s native wildlife.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Interior secretary, Ossoff visit Okefenokee as mining project advances
Preview: With a controversial plan to mine titanium near the edge of the Okefenokee National Wildlife Refuge still alive, U.S. Sec. of the Interior Deb Haaland and Sen. Jon Ossoff paid a visit to the swamp.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Democrat fights to stay in Public Service Commission race amid ...
Preview: A Democratic Public Service Commission (PSC) candidate facing disqualification challenged the state’s residency requirement in court Tuesday, arguing a judge should allow her to stay in the race, in part due to an alleged campaign by her opponent to draw her out of the district boundaries.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Milliken: Georgia textile plant with history of pollution violations will ...
Preview: The Milliken & Company textile plant, which has a history of pollution violations along the Ogeechee River in eastern Georgia, announced Wednesday that it plans to shut down for good.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Shoe company Okabashi Brands will renovate its Gwinnett plant and ...
Preview: Gwinnett County-based sandal and flip-flop manufacturer Okabashi Brands announced Thursday that it will invest $20 million and create 340 new jobs over the next five years as it renovates and expands its Buford production plant.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Georgia Power will turn millions more tons of coal ash into concrete
Preview: On Wednesday, the Georgia Power announced plans to begin harvesting roughly 600,000 tons of coal ash each year from Plant Bowen near Cartersville to produce concrete for roads, buildings and bridges across Georgia.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Inflation Reduction Act a wrench in Hyundai plans for Georgia ...
Preview: Hyundai Motor Group’s plans to break ground on a new electric vehicle factory near the Georgia coast have been complicated by a sprawling climate law signed last month by President Joe Biden, which was intended, in part, to spur more domestic production of EVs.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Okefenokee mine project dealt major blow by Army Corps of ...
Preview: A controversial titanium mine planned on the doorstep of the Okefenokee National Wildlife Refuge was dealt a major blow Friday when the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers moved to restore federal oversight of the project.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Hyundai presses U.S. government for flexibility with EV tax credits
Preview: Korean officials and Hyundai Motor Group used the occasion of its Georgia EV plant groundbreaking to urge Washington to restore tax credits for plug-in vehicles Hyundai currently makes in Korea until it can start production in the U.S.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Hurricane Ian: Largely spared, Georgia looks to help neighboring ...
Preview: St. Simons Island - Friday in coastal Georgia was a day of cleanup for some and feeling thankful for many.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Georgia weather: Why we may be in for a warm fall and winter
Preview: The hotter than normal temperatures that Georgia has felt so far in 2022 are likely to continue into early fall and possibly beyond, a new federal forecast shows.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: How a rare voting rights win took two races off Georgia ballots
Preview: A rare voting rights victory in the courts resulted in the cancellation of this year's elections for Georgia's utility regulatory board, the Public Service Commission. The case went all the way to the U.S. Supreme Court after a federal judge decided that at-large, statewide elections for the Public Service Commission illegally diluted the voting power of Black Georgians.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Coastal Georgia businesses exhale as Hurricane Ian skirts by
Preview: Coastal businesses in Georgia escaped most of the impact of Hurricane Ian.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Georgia Power settles cost dispute with Vogtle co-owner
Preview: Georgia Power will pay $76 million to settle a cost-sharing dispute with a co-owner of the new nuclear reactors under construction at Plant Vogtle near Augusta, putting an end to one of several disagreements tied to the project’s still rising price tag.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: As Vogtle's nuclear units move toward completion, rate hikes lie ahead
Preview: Georgia Power and Southern Nuclear staff said this week that the two new nuclear reactors under construction at Plant Vogtle remain on track to begin generating electricity next year, but rate increases are on the horizon for the company's customers.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Southern Company earnings jump to $1.5 billion in third quarter
Preview: Earnings for Atlanta-based utility giant Southern Company, the parent of Georgia Power, rose for the second-straight quarter, driven mainly by increases in usage and the rates the customers are charged for electricity, as well as continued progress on the two new nuclear reactors at Plant Vogtle, the company said.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Rivian project gets federal wetlands permit, site work to expand
Preview: Rivian’s $5 billion electric vehicle factory planned for a rural site an hour east of Atlanta cleared a major environmental hurdle Wednesday, when the federal government granted the project a key permit allowing the state to begin grading the entire 2,000-acre site.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Some candidates bashed the Rivian EV deal. Here's how they fared.
Preview: While the Rivian EV plant remains a hot topic for those living near the future site, political candidates who tried to channel the frustrations of residents struggled in Georgia's primary elections.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Winter weather in Georgia forecast to be warmer and drier than normal
Preview: A warmer and drier than normal winter is likely in store for most of Georgia, a new federal forecast released Thursday shows.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Don't panic, Kemp tells Georgians as Hurricane Ian pounds Florida
Preview: Hurricane Ian devastates Florida on its way to southeast Georgia.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: AJC expands climate coverage with grant support
Preview: The Kendeda Fund and 1Earth Fund have committed $50,000 in a one-year grant to increase the AJC’s reporting on climate change and its effects on metro Atlanta residents, businesses and other institutions.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: House passes federal health care, tax and climate change bill; how ...
Preview: The U.S. House delivered another major legislative victory for President Joe Biden on Friday. The vote was 220-207. Every Georgia Democrat voted for the package, while all state Republicans opposed it. The measure now goes to the president for his signature.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: As powerful hurricane bears down on Florida, Georgia braces for a hit
Preview: Hurricane Ian could bring dangerous coastal storm surges, high winds and flash flooding to Georgia this week — but not the threat of catastrophic destruction the storm poses for Florida’s Gulf coast.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Georgia coast now in Ian's destructive path
Preview: The remnants of Hurricane Ian raged along the Georgia coast Thursday after leaving a wide trail of death and destruction across Florida.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Feds sue poultry producers, alleging unfair worker practices
Preview: WASHINGTON (AP) — The Justice Department filed a lawsuit Monday against some of the largest poultry producers in the U.S. along with a proposed settlement seeking to end what it claims have been longstanding deceptive and abusive practices for workers.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Georgia Ag department warns of citrus canker in commercial grove
Preview: The state Department of Agriculture is warning citrus growers about a bacteria detected in a commercial grove in South Georgia.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Republicans sweep down-ballot statewide races again
Preview: Republicans running statewide won the down-ballot races once  again.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Some firms expand health coverage after abortion ruling, others mum
Preview: Several top entertainment and technology companies with operations in Georgia said Friday they would move to expand employees’ access to abortion care in states where the procedure will be banned or curtailed after the U.S. Supreme Court struck down Roe v. Wade. But several large Atlanta-based employers stayed mum.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Monarch counts may not be as dire, but researchers are divided
Preview: Scientists say monarch butterflies are threatened by climate change, herbicide use and habitat destruction, but a new study by researchers, including two from the University of Georgia, suggests monarch butterflies may not be as threatened as previously thought.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Atlanta nonprofits to receive free EV charging stations
Preview: EnviroSpark, a Georgia-based electric vehicle (EV) charging company, announced plans Tuesday to open several charging stations around Atlanta in partnership with local nonprofits.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Profits, EV charging dominate latest round of Georgia Power hearings
Preview: Georgia Power and Public Service Commission members and staff clashed over how much profit the state’s largest utility will be able to make in the years ahead as state regulators resumed hearings Tuesday on proposed rate hikes that could affect 2.7 million Georgia Power customers.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Here are 3 ways the EPA can still regulate climate pollution
Preview: After West Virginia v. EPA, the Clean Air Act still holds the keys to climate action.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Driver ejected from car jumps into river, Florida officials say | Miami ...
Preview: Firefighters on jet skis rescued him from the water, officials said.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: In clean energy transition, Georgia is at the tip of the spear
Preview: The global economy is transitioning from one based on fossil fuels into one powered by cleaner sources, like wind and solar. And as it unfolds, Georgia is as well-positioned as any state to ride the wave.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Georgia's winter felt more like spring. Here's why that's concerning
Preview: Georgia and much of the eastern U.S. just experienced an exceptionally hot winter, which new federal data shows, recorded temperatures among the warmest for the state in 129 years of weather record-keeping.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Georgia lawmakers consider certification process for solar installers
Preview: A Georgia House bill would create a new certification process for all residential solar installers, which supporters say is needed to protect customers from a few “bad actors” who are scamming customers with expensive solar systems and false promises of free electricity.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Georgia plant gets $80 million grant to make jet fuel from wood chips
Preview: A Georgia plant turning wood residue into jet fuel is receiving a big chunk of new federal funding to boost production, in the hopes that its products can eventually lower the climate change impact of the airline industry and sectors.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: EPA floats tighter ethylene oxide standards and worker protections
Preview: The federal Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) is proposing tighter limits on air emissions and worker protections to reduce exposure to ethylene oxide, a colorless gas used to sterilize medical supplies and some food products that has been linked to cancer and other serious health conditions
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Georgia off to a record-warm start in 2023, new data shows
Preview: In 129 years of record-keeping, Georgia has never had a hotter start to a year than the one the state just experienced, new federal data released Monday shows.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Westside Lead Superfund site to get new EPA funds to speed up ...
Preview: The ongoing efforts to remove toxic lead-contaminated soils from several historically Black neighborhoods west of downtown Atlanta will receive new funding, federal officials announced Friday.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Another Vogtle reactor issue will delay new unit's operation
Preview: Georgia Power announced that “vibrations” within the cooling system of one of the two new nuclear reactors at Plant Vogtle were discovered during start-up testing, an issue that is likely to further delay the unit’s in-service date.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Georgia Power proposes steep rate increase for customers - How it ...
Preview: Just weeks after a major rate increase approved by state regulators began hitting many Georgians’ electricity bills, Georgia Power is asking to collect at least another $2.1 billion from rate payers to cover the cost of the coal, gas and nuclear fuel used in its power plants.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: 'Unusual' pipe support omission behind new Vogtle delay, witness ...
Preview: Vibration issues revealed last week inside one of Plant Vogtle’s two new nuclear units occurred because critical pipe support bracing was not installed, witnesses at a state hearing said Tuesday, calling the omission “unusual” and foreshadowing the possibility of more delays as testing on the unit progresses.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Why peaches from Georgia might be in short supply this year
Preview: Georgia peach farmers fear that an exceptionally warm winter followed by several days of freezing temperatures this month, may have inflicted a brutal, one-two punch that wiped out much of their crop.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Mayor's office revives Atlanta's 'Clean Energy Advisory Board'
Preview: Mayor Andre Dickens and Atlanta’s Chief Sustainability Officer Chandra Farley announced Friday that the city has relaunched its “Clean Energy Advisory Board” to help the city increase its use of clean energy and reduce its climate change impact.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: As Atlanta grows, its trademark tree canopy suffers
Preview: Atlanta has long been known as the "city in the forest," but analyses commissioned by city hall and recent data show Atlanta is losing its tree canopy at an increasing rate.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Georgia utility get funds to test removing 'forever chemicals' from ...
Preview: A Georgia utility facing lawsuits for allegedly polluting the main drinking water supply for communities downstream will receive federal funds to test methods for removing so-called “forever chemicals” -- also known as PFAS -- from wastewater it receives to treat.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Report: Okefenokee Swamp among country's 'most endangered ...
Preview: A new report released Tuesday says South Georgia’s famed Okefenokee Swamp is among the most endangered waterways in the country because of a proposed titanium mine planned less than three miles from the swamp’s edge.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Solar manufacturer Qcells confirms $2.5 billion Georgia expansion ...
Preview: Solar panel giant Qcells’ said Wednesday that it will spend $2.5 billion on a massive expansion of its Georgia production footprint, in what the company and federal and state officials say is the largest ever investment in clean energy manufacturing in U.S. history.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Atlanta's Mercedes-Benz Stadium earns zero waste certification
Preview: Atlanta’s Mercedes-Benz Stadium announced Monday that it has earned the Total Resource Use and Efficiency (TRUE) Platinum certification for its efforts to reduce waste, becoming the first professional sports stadium in the world to receive that designation.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Southern Co. reports big profit increase but costly Vogtle delays loom
Preview: Georgia Power’s parent Southern Company reported a jump of roughly $1.1 billion in its full year profits for 2022 compared to the previous year on Thursday, but once again extended its projected timeline for the two long-delayed and over-budget nuclear reactors at Plant Vogtle to begin generating electricity.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Georgia receives $54 million to remove 'forever chemicals'
Preview: Georgia will receive more than $54 million to clean up drinking water supplies in communities around the state that have been polluted by toxic “forever chemicals,” federal environmental officials announced this week.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Investigation underway into cause, impacts of Brunswick chemical fire
Preview: Authorities are investigating the cause and potential environmental impacts of a massive fire that occurred at a chemical plant in Brunswick on Saturday, which triggered evacuation orders and has left some residents leery of returning home, even after officials said it was safe to do so.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Bipartisan bill aims to protect Okefenokee Swamp from titanium mining
Preview: A south Georgia House Republican has renewed her efforts to prevent future mining near the Okefenokee National Wildlife Refuge, just as a years-long effort by an Alabama company to extract titanium near the swamp appears to be nearing the finish line.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Size of looming rate hike for Georgia Power customers comes into ...
Preview: Georgia Power and staff for state regulators at the Georgia Public Service Commission (PSC) have reached a tentative agreement to raise customers’ rates dramatically as soon as June 1 to cover the cost of the coal, gas and nuclear fuel used in its power plants.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Feds release EV charging standards to expand nationwide ...
Preview: The Biden administration released new domestic manufacturing standards Wednesday for federally-funded electric vehicle chargers and announced other investments officials say will help expand the country’s network of charging stations.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Solar panel maker Qcells expected to announce huge Georgia ...
Preview: Solar panel manufacturer Qcells is expected to announce an expansion in Dalton plus a massive new plant northwest of Atlanta as part of what could be the largest clean energy manufacturing investment in U.S history, multiple people with knowledge of the company’s plans told the The Atlanta Journal-Constitution.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Bird flu threatens bald eagles in Georgia and across North America
Preview: A highly contagious strain of bird flu that has ravaged wild bird populations globally is killing an unprecedented number of nesting bald eagles in coastal Georgia and Florida, according to a new study from UGA scientists and other researchers.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Solar parts supplier for Qcells building $147M plant northwest of ...
Preview: On the heels of solar giant Qcells’ plans to open a massive new manufacturing facility in Cartersville, a supplier announced Thursday it will invest $147 million to build a plant just down the road to make critical parts for the company’s panels.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Kemp unveils first set of EV chargers at Georgia's state parks
Preview: A short hike from the scenic trails and waterfalls of Tallulah Gorge, Gov. Brian Kemp revealed the Georgia State Parks system’s first EV chargers on Thursday and announced plans to install more at other parks with the help of partners Rivian, Georgia Power and the Department of Natural Resources.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Biden trade chief to visit Atlanta before president's MLK Jr. Day trip
Preview: The nation’s top trade official is coming to Atlanta this week to showcase President Joe Biden’s economic accomplishments ahead of the president’s planned appearance Sunday at Ebenezer Baptist Church for the birthday celebration of The Rev. Martin Luther King Jr.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Georgia Power says Plant Vogtle Unit 3 has started generating ...
Preview: One of the two long-delayed nuclear units at Plant Vogtle near Augusta successfully generated electricity and connected to the grid for the first time, Georgia Power announced Saturday morning.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: EV and solar bills expected during legislative session
Preview: As Georgia's legislative session approaches, EV charging, rooftop solar and a controversial Okefenokee mine are among the environmental issues expected to take center stage under the Golden Dome.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Georgia getting $120 million to remove lead pipes, 'forever chemicals'
Preview: Georgia is set to receive nearly $120 million to replace dangerous lead pipes around the stat and clean-up of drinking water in communities whose supplies are contaminated by toxic pollutants like “forever chemicals,” the federal government announced Tuesday.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Georgia Power begins splitting atoms inside one of new Vogtle ...
Preview: One of the two new nuclear reactors nearing completion at Plant Vogtle has reached initial criticality, Georgia Power said Wednesday, a key milestone that brings the unit closer to delivering electricity to Georgians.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Black communities burdened by air pollution may finally get answers
Preview: Many Black communities around Atlanta have voiced concerns about pollution for years but have lacked data to support their claims. Now, a series of new initiatives and studies aim to provide the data they’ve craved.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Forecast predicts slightly less active Atlantic hurricane season
Preview: An influential group of researchers is predicting that the 2023 hurricane season will be slightly less active than normal, but conflicting signals from both the Pacific and Atlantic Ocean means their forecast carries more uncertainty than in years past.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: As Atlanta's new tree rules kick in, advocates push stronger standards
Preview: A set of modest changes to Atlanta’s tree protection ordinance passed late last year by City Council took effect Thursday, marking the first revisions to the rules governing tree removals and replacements in the city in years.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Qcells partners with Microsoft to advance its clean energy goals
Preview: Georgia solar panel manufacturer Qcells announced Wednesday that is joining forces with technology and software giant Microsoft to help the company achieve its renewable energy goals.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Fed scientists ID 'critical shortcomings' in plan to mine near ...
Preview: Federal scientists have delivered their most detailed critique yet of an Alabama company’s plan to mine near the Okefenokee National Wildlife Refuge, casting serious doubt on the claims of the company and state environmental regulators, who have repeatedly said the project poses no harm to the refuge.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Georgia Power customers to receive a one-time credit on March bills
Preview: Georgia Power customers will get a modest, one-time credit on their March bills.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Endangered Right Whale freed from fishing gear off Georgia coast
Preview: Georgia wildlife biologists and other staff helped free an endangered North Atlantic Right Whale from most of the fishing gear it was tangled in late last month, a rare success story for a species facing the threat of extinction.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Draft plans released for controversial Okefenokee titanium mine
Preview: Draft mining plans for a controversial titanium mine that would operate on the doorstep of the Okefenokee National Wildlife Refuge were released Thursday by state environmental regulators, a major development in a years-long fight over the project.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: He put solar panels on his roof. Now his metro Atlanta HOA wants ...
Preview: With generous tax incentives available and power bills climbing, many Georgians are exploring rooftop solar. But often their plans to power their homes with the sun's rays are being stymied by homeowners associations that wield considerable power over the decisions owners can make about their own property.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Southern Company, Georgia Power announce executive leadership ...
Preview: Southern Company, the Atlanta-based utility giant announced a major shake up in its leadership ranks that will see the current head of its largest subsidiary, Georgia Power, assume control of the company.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Atlanta area cybersecurity giant Secureworks announces layoffs
Preview: Metro Atlanta cybersecurity giant Secureworks said Tuesday it would cut nearly one-tenth of its global workforce, citing the need to reduce spending and shift the focus of its business.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Republicans call to repeal clean energy incentives amid Georgia ...
Preview: Republicans used a congressional field hearing in suburban Atlanta to amplify the party’s call to roll back green energy tax incentives that were the centerpiece of President Joe Biden’s climate change law.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Georgia officials announce bipartisan hydrogen energy 'braintrust'
Preview: Jon Ossoff, Georgia’s Democratic U.S. senator, and Tim Echols, the Republican vice chair of the state’s utilities regulator, have teamed up to create a coalition of experts and business leaders to promote Georgia as a center for hydrogen energy.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: New Gwinnett commissioner is outnumbered but undaunted
Preview: Matthew Holtkamp is continuing to push support for law enforcement and property tax relief.
Key.Author: Drew Kann

Article.Title: Charles Stanley, well-known preacher and evangelical broadcaster ...
Preview: Atlanta's Rev. Charles Stanley, internationally known evangelical pastor, dies.
Key.Author: Drew Kann
